intro.title: ― Painting Dreams on the Canvas of Logic ―
paragraphs: We aim to expand intuitive understanding by exploring materials science from new perspectives, discover research opportunities through emerging technologies, and guide researchers worldwide to these discoveries. We strive to build inclusive research teams where people from diverse backgrounds can contribute their unique strengths, pursuing research driven by genuine scientific need rather than metrics. This page introduces our research activities guided by these principles.

projects.title: Research Overview
content: We develop original Materials Informatics methods for new applications in materials science. Our main achievements include the Starrydata database for extracting material properties from published graphs, Elemental Reactivity Maps for predicting ternary compound formation through machine learning, and the Crystal Structure Simulator for 3D crystal design.

Successful research depends on effective collaboration. Our work has grown through partnerships with academic and industrial researchers, students, engineers, and users whose diverse interests have broadened our research scope.

Our group is based at NIMS (Namiki district) with an affiliated position at the University of Tsukuba's International Materials Innovation Graduate Program. We teach Materials Informatics in English (October-December) and supervise graduate students in Master's and Doctoral programs.
We welcome inquiries from those interested in these research areas or potential collaboration. We can work together to develop research strategies aligned with your objectives.

projects.title: Materials Informatics
content: Materials Informatics applies data science to materials science. By analyzing large-scale datasets, we can identify patterns in materials behavior and enable strategic research planning. Machine learning captures empirical knowledge that theoretical calculations alone cannot reproduce, making expert-level materials development accessible to newcomers.

The field centers on methodology development—finding effective combinations of datasets and algorithms, then rigorously evaluating their performance. This interdisciplinary work requires expertise in both materials science and computational methods.

As an emerging field, MI offers numerous unexplored research opportunities. Young researchers can establish themselves as experts in this open, collaborative environment that values contribution over seniority.

We have launched three major projects: Starrydata for systematic data extraction from literature, Elemental Reactivity Maps for compound formation prediction, and Crystal Structure Simulator for intuitive structure design. These tools support materials discovery across the research community.

projects.title: Starrydata
content: Starrydata is a unique open database project extracting material property data from graphs in scientific papers. Launched in 2015, it addresses the critical shortage of experimental data needed for Materials Informatics.

Scientific papers contain valuable experimental data in graph format. By digitizing and sharing this data, Starrydata enables large-scale data analysis for all researchers. The current Starrydata2 system hosts the world's largest experimental database for thermoelectric materials.

Starting with support from the Japan Society of Thermoelectric Power Generation in 2015, the project evolved through the NIMS MI2I project and RIKEN AIP collaboration, becoming an official NIMS project in 2020. Our dedicated data collection team maintains high-quality standards through systematic paper analysis.

Future development focuses on expanding participation, implementing AI-assisted extraction, and extending coverage to additional materials classes, establishing Starrydata as essential infrastructure for data-driven materials research.

projects.title: Elemental Reactivity Maps
content: We developed Elemental Reactivity Maps, a new tool that uses machine learning to predict compound formation for all possible 1-, 2-, and 3-element combinations. The system consists of 80 matrices (80×80 elements each) covering the complete ternary chemical space.

Existing compounds appear in red tones (maroon to yellow), while unreported combinations show in blue tones (navy to light blue). Color intensity indicates machine learning formation probability, providing quantitative synthesis guidance.

This concept emerged from doctoral research on metal borides. Analysis of 700+ ternary borides revealed systematic gaps in compound space. Targeted synthesis in these gaps produced new materials including Ca1+eCo4B4 and Ca1+eRu4B4 with incommensurate structures.
The tool transforms expert intuition into quantitative predictions accessible to all researchers. It identifies both promising synthesis targets and combinations unlikely to form compounds.

projects.title: Crystal Structure Simulator
content: While crystal structures involve complex mathematics, they are fundamentally patterns of atoms arranged in 3D space. We developed the Crystal Structure Simulator as a web application that lets users build crystals interactively, making crystallography accessible without specialized training.

Users select elements to generate spheres scaled to atomic/ionic radii, position them with mouse controls, and receive real-time feedback on bond distances through color coding. The system supports standard CIF format for compatibility with existing workflows.
We analyzed 30,000+ stable compounds to create a database of atomic arrangement patterns found in real crystals. This enables structure prediction based on chemical similarity to known compounds.

Future plans include educational content development, molecular dynamics integration for stability assessment, and catalyst design applications. We seek collaborators interested in extending functionality or developing specialized applications.

projects.title: Thermoelectric Materials Research
content: Thermoelectric materials convert between heat and electricity through the Seebeck effect (temperature gradient to voltage) and Peltier effect (current to temperature gradient). These materials enable waste heat recovery and solid-state cooling. We work to discover materials with improved thermoelectric performance and establish design principles.

We combine first-principles calculations with Starrydata's experimental database to identify performance-limiting factors. Our analysis highlights band gap optimization and band degeneracy engineering as key strategies, while also targeting materials with favorable electronic structures.

With 15+ years in thermoelectric research spanning theory, synthesis, and device development, we contribute to the field through board membership in the Japan Society of Thermoelectric Power Generation, educational activities, and machine learning applications for accelerated materials screening.

projects.title: New Materials Discovery
content: New materials discovery involves finding compounds with unreported compositions or structures that may exhibit unexpected properties. We combine data analysis, chemical intuition, and Elemental Reactivity Map predictions for efficient exploration.

In metal borides, we established rules governing boron network formation (icosahedra, honeycomb sheets) and synthesized numerous new compounds. We now collaborate with experimental groups, providing data-driven synthesis recommendations.

Unexpected products often prove more interesting than initial targets. Our flexible approach accommodates both targeted and exploratory synthesis, maximizing discovery potential across diverse chemical systems.

projects.title: Superconductor Research
content: Superconductors exhibit zero electrical resistance below critical temperatures (Tc), enabling applications in MRI systems, maglev trains, and quantum computers. We pursue discovery of practical superconductors with higher operating temperatures.

Previous work involved atomic-resolution structural characterization of novel superconductors using transmission electron microscopy, including structure determination of iron-based superconductors. Current efforts explore data-driven approaches to accelerate superconductor discovery.

projects.title: MgB<sub>2</sub> Critical Current Enhancement
content: MgB2 (Tc=39K) shows promise for practical superconducting applications. Undergraduate research demonstrated critical current improvement through microstructure optimization. Flux pinning centers—intentionally introduced defects—prevent flux motion that causes resistance.

Systematic studies identified grain boundaries as primary pinning sites in MgB<sub>2</sub>. Processing with fine boron powder under Mg-deficient conditions achieved enhanced performance through grain refinement and densification. These principles now guide commercial MgB<sub>2</sub> wire production.
